Thanks to her perseverance, now she is happy with the business she has, and is grateful to Kiva partner MFP at the same time for giving her this loan to help her increase her capital. Now all she does is provide good products at reasonable prices, and what matters most is the special treatment she offers to all of her customers. This is her first loan with MFP, and she promises to make her payments on time. Norma feels happy and grateful to her community bank for welcoming her with open arms. With the 1,000 soles, she plans to invest in the purchase of new products for her cafe.

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of new products for her cafe.

loans.name: Getrude

texts.en:
Getrude is single, 29 years old, and has one child. She runs a beauty salon. She has been doing this business for the last three years, and earns an income of KES 10,000 (Kenyan shillings) per month.

She is applying for her second loan of KES 60,000 from KADET LTD. With the loan, she plans to purchase beauty products like braids, hair chemicals, shampoos, conditioner, creams etc. She will use the anticipated profit to expand her business and educate her child.

Getrude hopes to have the best salon in the area of Lucky Summer.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products like braids, hair chemicals, shampoos, conditioner, creams etc.

loans.name: Mahbuba

texts.ru: Махбуба проживает в районе Хуросон. Возраст, 25 лет. Разведена. Имеет одного ребенка. Сейчас она живет вместе с родителями. Ее отец и брат находятся в России. Сама Махбуба занимается торговлей фруктов и овощей. Этим видом деятельности она занимается 8 лет. Кредит берет для покупки яблок, винограда, риса и масла.
texts.en: Mahbuba lives in the Khuroson district.  She is 25 years old, divorced and has one child.  Currently, she lives together with her parents.  Her father and brother are in Russia.  Mahbuba is involved in sales of fruits and vegetables.  She has been in this business for eight years.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of apples, grapes, rice and oil.

loans.use: to buy apples, grapes, rice and oil

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en:
Alfred is a 51-year-old married man with six children, living in his own house in Masindi, Uganda. His family's dream is to educate his children to higher levels of education. Alfred is a cattle keeper and he has been in the business for 10 years. Alfred started with only one cow but now has 11 cows and five calves from which he is able to generate 30 litres of milk per day. Each litre is sold at 800 Ugandan shillings only. Hardships in the business are the lack of pasture and water during the dry season. His dream is to own a big farm.

Alfred needs the loan facility to buy cows for rearing.

loans.use: To buy cows for rearing.

loans.name: Librada

texts.en:
Librada is from the village of Dinas, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She is the mother of two adult-aged children. They stand as the living witnesses of the hard work and sacrifices their parents have endured just to provide what they need and want. Librada started running a retail store with a small capital many years ago. This helps to sustain daily needs and enhance her entrepreneurial ability allowing her to earn PHP 3,500 (Philippine pesos) a month. In 2006, Librada joined GDMPC to ease the difficulty of financing for business subsistence and expansion. 

The cooperative allowed her a loan of PHP 10,000 to obtain grocery products to sell. She will be able to make a favorable profit to uplift the family's living  status.

loans.use: To obtain grocery products to sell.

loans.name: Zaituna

texts.ru:
Зайтуна очень хорошая и порядочная женщина. Она вдова и у неё один ребенок Она сама занимается купля продажей продукты питания более 4 года. Она любить свою работу и с удовольствием занимается этим. Её торговая точка находится возле своего дома и её систра помогает ей в данном бизнесе. Она хочет расширить свой бизнес и получить хороший прибыль для того чтобы она могла содержать своего ребенка и обеспечить его. Она хочет устроит своего ребенка в садик, чтобы он вырос умным и воспитанным ребенком.  Зайтуна хотела бы получит кредит в размере 3000$ США для покупки нового ассортимента продукты питания. Она надеется, что кредиторы будут поддерживать её. 

 More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj
texts.en: Zaituna is a very good and decent woman.  She is a widow and has one child.  She has been involved in buying and selling food products for over four years.  She loves her work and does it with satisfaction.  Her retail outlet is located near her home, and her sister helps her in this business.  Zaituna wants to expand her business and make a good profit in order to support her child and provide for him.  She wants to place her child into a kindergarten, so that he grows up to become a smart and well-mannered person.  Zaituna wants to obtain a loan in the sum of $3000 for the purchase of a new assortment of food products.  She hopes that the creditors will support her.

loans.use: to buy food products

loans.name: Anabelle

texts.en:
Anabelle is a 50-year-old mother of four dependents. It is in Calamba, Misamis Occidental, Philippines, that the family settled down and runs a retail store for a living. All family members help each other to accommodate customers. She always reminds her children to be thrifty and to manage resources timely and properly to succeed. By the end of the month, Anabelle's cash on hand reaches a total of PHP 9,000 (Philippine pesos) from store operations.

Earlier this year, Anabelle became a GDMPC member. Her former loan application has been paid in full. Now, she is requesting a loan of PHP 6,000 to change the store roof and cover holes in some corners, so it is a conducive place to do business. She hopes for a progressive business venture and to lay aside a sum of money as a revolving fund.

loans.use: To change the store roof and cover holes in some corners.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena, a 47-year-old widow with four grown children, lives in Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur Philippines, where her small piggery is located. In this business for three years, she earns PHP 5,000 a month and allots time each day caring for and feeding the pigs and cleaning out their shelter. As well, she closely monitors their health.

A member of GDMPC since 2010, Elena is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000 to purchase feeds and other supplies. In the future, she hopes to increase her number of piglets and other livestock to raise her income. Additional revenue will be allocated to widening the animal enclosure.

loans.use: to purchase feeds and other supplies.

loans.name: Shiella Mae

texts.en:
For the past six years Shiella Mae, a 22-year-old married resident of Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines, has raised a variety of of fish to sell in the town market and on an individual order basis. Along with other irregular sources of income, she earns PHP 15,000 a month.

Shiella Mae is receiving her first loan of PHP 30,000 from GDMPC to expand her production of fish. This year she expects to reap a good harvest and obtain a very favorable price for her fish. Profits will be used to buy more fish and feed.

loans.use: to expand fish production.

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie is from Poblacion, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. She is now 31 years old, married and operates a fish vending stall in the town market. This crowded, noisy and messy place of business is not new to her anymore, since the time she entered and became one of the occupants. In spite of it all, Elvie loves the place. Her family has had alternative sources of income, but this is the one they've relied upon most. She makes 51,750 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

Elvie was invited by a friend to join GDMPC, which she did in 2010. She has requested a loan of 35,000 PHP to invest in expanding her fish selling business. It is the third loan transaction Elvie has completed with GDMPC. She longs to expand her business array and invest in related business sectors to increase her day-to-day inflows.

loans.use: to invest in expanding a fish selling business.

loans.name: Sou

texts.en:
Mrs. Sou, 32, is a married woman and has two children who live on her income. Currently, she is a pig raiser. She has been running this business for many years. She earns about $3 US per day. For two months, her pigs weren't growing well, so she intends to use the loan to buy feed concentrate to fatten the pigs up. She owns several pigs and she intends to feed them concentrate to fatten them up more quickly. She wants her animals to reach ideal weight to sell in the local and nearby markets. She wants to earn higher profits for her family's and her parents’ well-being and to expand this pig-raising project. 

This is Mrs. Sou's first loan with Kiva. She’s had no previous loans from state banks, but Hattha Kaksekar Ltd. offered the best terms and a much lower interest rate. So, she would like to request some funds to purchase pig feed.

loans.use: to purchase pig feed.

loans.name: Mildred

texts.en:
Mildred is from Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. She is 45 years old and has two children. For the past 21 years of married life, she has been selling seafood in the marketplace and dealing with different people in a favorable manner. She maintains good relationships with her fellow vendors and, topmost, to her customers. Her family has other sources of income but selling seafood is the main cash provider for the family. She earns 38,250 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from her businesses.  

Mildred is a member of GDMPC. She has already taken out several loans from the organization and repaid them well. This year, she is applying for a loan of 35,000 PHP to acquire additional seafood products to sell. This loan molds her ability to engage in business. As time goes by, Mildred aims to sustain and expand her business to increase her monthly sales rate.

loans.use: to acquire additional seafood products to sell.

loans.name: Pilar

texts.en: Pilar is a married woman living in Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She has two school-aged children. She operates a motor transport business to make a living. It has been running for about three years already. She has habal-habal, as the folks call it, [a motorcycle] that carries 2-4 passengers and is advantageous for traveling in remote or rural areas. She earns 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from this job. In 2007, Pilar joined GDMPC to have a way in to financial services. She borrowed several times from the coop and successfully repaid in full. This year, 2011, she applied for a loan of 8,000 PHP to repair an engine and push through with her daily work routine. After this loan, she anticipates requesting another one for further business enhancement and to materialize her plans for expansion.

loans.use: to repair an engine.

loans.name: Angelito

texts.en:
To earn additional income, Angelito plants, harvests, and sells corn. He is 43 years old and has three school-aged children. He and his family live in a village where their primary income comes from planting and harvesting rice. Angelito strives to improve their standard of living and to continue sending their children to school. He wants his children to become professionals some day. Despite hardships and difficulties, they are working hard to earn an income in order to meet their basic necessities and to finance the education of their children.

Angelito hopes to increase his income by improving his yield in corn production. Due to lack of capital, he is asking for a loan of 20,000 PHP to buy corn seed, fertilizers, and pesticides, and to pay for labor required in corn production. He believes that the loan will help him to increase his yields. He hopes that, some day, he will become financially stable.

loans.use: to buy corn seed, fertilizers, and pesticides, and to pay labor required in corn production

loans.name: Marialita

texts.en:
Marialita is a mother of three school-aged children. She is 45 years old, married and lives in Katipunan, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. Her husband is a driver and she, to help, runs a retail store. There are many competitors in this line of business but Marialita does her best not to be left behind. She has had this store for over five years. She is able to generate a total of PHP 6,300 (Philippine pesos) a month. 

Marialita is asking for a loan of PHP 12,000 through GDMPC, a cooperative of which she became a member in 2006. With the loan she will acquire additional goods to sell for a profit. With the growing rate of competitors in the same line of business, she hopes to keep going and aspires to exist for many long years and not be pulled down by inevitable circumstance. She wants to develop and improve her entrepreneurial activities to earn more income.

loans.use: To acquire additional goods to sell.

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
The person covered in this page is Rosalie. She is 28 years old and married. In Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines, she peddles food items around nearby communities or within the community itself to earn a living. She is named as one of the courteous food vendors in the area in which she has worked for 2 years. Every month, she earns 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP).

Rosalie is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP at GDMPC to buy food supplies for a vending job. She was registered as a member in the cooperative earlier this year. Getting involved in this borrowing activity is a way that she can sustain her work and continue what she is doing today. She aims to own an ordinary food stand in the area and sell the best saleable items.

loans.use: to buy food supplies for a vending job.

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios is a widow. She is now 58 years old with two grown-up children. She owns a vacant lot which she cultivates to earn a living. Gardening is the work she started three years ago. She grows many varieties of crops which she sells in turn to neighbors, mini-markets and nearby communities. This gives her a monthly income of 1,000 Philippine pesos (PHP).

Remedios joined GDMPC to access its financial services. She has confidence from past loans taken out. Loans prior to this request have been repaid. The current loan of 3,000 PHP is intended to buy seeds and seedlings to plant. In the future, she hopes to continue this activity for long, long years and earn more income from it. Increased revenue is planned with widening of the business area.

loans.use: to buy seeds and seedlings to plant.

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita is 26 years old, married and has two school-aged children. The whole family is living together in Jimenez, Misamis Occidental, Philippines where she owns and operates a retail store that has existed for over 3 years. She is able to generate 1,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month - a small amount, but Juanita has learned to apportion it well.

A loan of 6,000 PHP from GDMPC will help Juanita to obtain grocery products to sell. Competitors may arise anytime they want so Juanita is doing her best not to be left behind. She deals with her customers in a most favorable manner to keep them coming and make them regular customers. Juanita is planning to expand her business to improve general living condition for her family.

loans.use: to obtain grocery products to sell.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty is a 24-year-old married woman with one child. Her husband is a teacher by profession. She lives in a house in Masindi, Uganda. She has been selling cereals for two years now. With the income generated, she has been able to educate her children. Betty started her business with only 200,000 UGX (Ugandan shillings) but it has grown and now has a capital of 1,000,000 UGX. Hardships she faces in the business include poor roads for transporting products from villages to her store. Her dream is to run a big food store. Betty needs the loan facility to buy groundnuts and beans to sell.

loans.use: To buy groundnuts and beans to sell.

loans.name: Frese

texts.en:
Frese is a single entrepreneur from Jimenez, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. Growing flowers has long been her passion, which is the reason she started her flower business. Flowers are a very nice ornament to beautify inside and outside the house, streets, malls, and anywhere else. She started her business two years ago and makes 2,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

Last year, 2010, Frese became part of the GDMPC family. Her first loan taken out from the cooperative was repaid in full, and now she has applied for her second. It is for 30,000 PHP which is to purchase flower varieties and pots. By the end of the year, she hopes to sell plenty of flower varieties and obtain more to expand the business and meet her daily needs.

loans.use: to purchase flower varieties and pots.

loans.name: Mirzomahmad

texts.ru: Мирзомахмад проживает в районе Хуросон. Ему 42 года. Он женат. У него пятеро детей. Его жена занимается торговлей одежды на рынке. Сам он тоже занимается торговлей. Он в основном продает продукты питания. В этой области он 15 лет. Мирзомахмад имеет высшее образование, бухгалтер. По профессии проработал 6 лет. Он берет кредит для покупки сахара, масла, муки, натуральных соков и мороженного.
texts.en: Mirzomahmad lives in the Khuroson district.  He is 42 years old, married and has five children.  His wife is involved in sales of clothing at the market.  Mirzomahmad is also involved in sales.  He primarily sells food products and has been in this business for 15 years.  Mirzomahmad has a higher education as an accountant.  He spent six years working in that field.  He is requesting this loan for the purchase of sugar, oil, flour, natural juices and ice-cream.

loans.use: to buy sugar, oil, flour, natural juices and ice-cream

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea, 52, is living in Baray District, Kompong Thom Province, Cambodia. She lives with Yong, 53, and their three children whom they care for and provide with a good education. Now, one of her children has already married and lives independently. Chea strives to provide the best for her family members; she works hard for them in her fields planted with rice, corn and bananas. She’s been in this line of work for many years on land of her own. 

Taking time from the farming business, she run a business as a fish seller in one market near her community. From this business, she earns approximately $2 per day. To upgrade her family to be more comfortable, Chea would like to raise a cow but lacks capital, so she has already decided to request some funds through HKL, a partner with Kiva.This is her second loan with HKL; therefore, she’s hoping for a small loan to reach her objectives, and she is naturally disposed to repay her loan punctually. She hopes that this loan will make her family meet with happiness and prosperity all the time.

loans.use: to purchase a cow.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is one of the Philippine's small-scale entrepreneurs situated in Jimenez, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She is 52 years of age with two grown children. She owns and operates a retail store that has existed for more than 18 years already - quite long enough. She sells daily-use commodities and is a customer-oriented person. Every month, she earns 2,000 Philippines pesos (PHP).

Lydia joined GDMPC in the year 2006. She made several loan transactions from the organization and now is on her ninth loan. It is a loan worth PHP 5,000, with which she intends to purchase additional goods to sell. She hopes to expand her business range and repair the store's look to increase sales.

loans.use: To purchase additional goods to sell.

loans.name: Felipe

texts.en: Felipe is married and a father of two adult-aged children. He is from Punta Pana-on, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. Four years ago, he started working on a motorcycle transport activity. Folks called it a habal-habal that carries two to four passengers. In a month, he receives 2,500 Philippines pesos (PHP), proportionately divided for the whole family. Felipe gained access to GDMPC's financial services in 2010. Former loans he has drawn out from the cooperative have been paid successfully. Again, he is requesting a loan of PHP 15,000 to repair his motorcycle to regain its speed and renew its appearance. He hopes that with this loan, he can resume his job and expand his vehicle's seating capacity to accommodate more passengers to increase the flow of income.

loans.use: To repair his motorcycle.

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida is a mother of nine dependents, and she is 46 years old. She owns and operates a tailoring shop in Libertad Bajo, Misamis Occidental, Philippines, where she lives. The business commenced 13 years ago and continues today. She really has skills in mending, creating and designing dresses of any kind - uniforms, casual dresses, capes, etc. She earns approximately 6,000 Philippines pesos (PHP)  a month.

In 2006, Zenaida joined GDMPC. She enjoys the benefits of the services offered by the organization. It is an advantage to help carry out her business plans, and they are a good partner too. She took out loans before from GDMPC and has paid them in full. This year, Zenaida wants to borrow PHP 15,000 to purchase sewing tools such as scissors, textiles, threads, etc. She hopes to expand her business operations and not be left behind in society's current trends of fashion by keeping materials at all times.

loans.use: To purchase sewing tools such as scissors, textiles, threads, etc.

loans.name: Mayomae

texts.en:
Mayomae is a resident of Calamba, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She is married and 35 years old with three school-aged dependents. She started running her retail store three years ago. It's a small-scale business, but it is providing just income for the family. Monthly earnings of 5,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) are generated from business operations.

This year, she joined GDMPC to access financial services. She is requesting a loan of PHP 8,000 from the cooperative to buy additional grocery items to sell. She is planning to work hard and expand her business range, which she hopes to attain in the future in God's favor.

loans.use: To buy additional grocery items to sell.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is from Calamba, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She runs a sari-sari store in the place to obtain daily income for the household. She is 48 years old, married and is raising her two grown dependents. Her husband is also working for the family, which has allowed her to own PHP 7,000 a month. The store offers grocery items and other supplies that surely meet market demands. 

Sarah became interested in what her neighbors told her about GDMPC, a reason why she too joined the organization. Her first loan application of PHP 6,000 has been approved, allowing her to purchase additional goods to sell. She aspires to expand and improve the business operations for better living.

loans.use: To purchase additional goods to sell.

loans.name: Rissa

texts.en:
Rissa is a mother of two school-aged children. She is from Calamba, Misamis Occidental, Philippines where her retail store is located. This has allowed her to have a monthly income of PHP 8,000, part of which comes from impermanent jobs. She has been operating the store for four years and is so glad to have reached that far despite an increasing number of competitors.

A loan of PHP 6,000 from GDMPC will help Rissa to purchase small-sized showcases to organize her stock and determine goods easily. She hopes to obtain a good profit from this investment and maintain a good flow of earnings from the business. She aspires to send her children to a reputable school when they get into college to obtain a proper education and build a brighter future.

loans.use: To purchase small showcases to organize her stock.

loans.name: Jonard

texts.en:
Jonard is 37 years old, married and has three school-aged children. The family is residing in Calamba, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. It's been Jonard's dream to own a motorcycle for subsistence, which was brought into reality through hard work and determination. From that time on, he actively drives and sends passengers to designated areas safely.  It allows him to earn PHP 10,000 a month, considering other sources of irregular income, too.

A loan of PHP 50,000 from GDMPC will absolutely help Jonard to repair his motorcycle. The availability of this fund is a channel to facilitate operations immediately. With this loan, Jonard is expecting to pursue his job with a motor vehicle in good running condition to provide satisfactory service to customers. He hopes to sustain the daily needs and improve further service capacity.

loans.use: To repair his motorcycle.

loans.name: Cristiana

texts.en:
Cristiana is 49 years old and has four dependents; all are attending school. She established a retail store in Calamba, Misamis Occidental, Philippines, which is her place of residence. Her store has existed for over four years and constantly caters to community members' basic needs and other necessities for subsistence. She earns a total of 8,000 Philippines pesos (PHP)  a month.

Cristiana is a member of GDMPC, joining this year. This is her second time to borrow from the cooperative PHP 6,000. The money will be used to acquire additional goods to sell for a profit. As time goes on, Cristiana hopes to sustain store operations and expand her business range to improve the general living conditions of the family.

loans.use: To acquire additional goods to sell.

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
At the age of 44, Amelia already has 5 grown children who, when they have no classes to attend, help her in assisting customers in the eatery she owns. The business is strategically located in Calamba, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. Life has been like this for her since way back 3 years ago, and she is happy to operate such a business relating to foods. She loves cooking - a prime reason why the business exists. Every end of the month, Amelia earns a total of PHP 10,000 which is apportioned well to household expenses and business too.

It was in 2010 that Amelia found a way to avail herself of the financial services of GDMPC. The loans prior to this loan request of PHP 20,000 have been paid in full. The current loan application is intended to purchase a bulk amount of soft and hard drinks. To avoid being scarce of this resource (drinks), she requested this loan. As time goes on, Amelia aspires to upgrade her business offers and acquire enough supplies of materials needed to keep it going.

loans.use: To purchase bulk soft and hard drinks to sell

loans.name: Kwamenkuruma Group

texts.en:
Ibrahim, who is in his late 20s, is single with one small son. He has been running a retail shop for two and half years now.  He works from 6 am to 10 pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.
 
This will be his first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania, which he wants to use to increase the shop's inventory. His dream is to one day be able to build his own house. 

He will share this loan with his loan group "Kwamenkuruma", which has a total of 15 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

loans.use: To increase the shop inventory.

loans.name: Renante

texts.en:
Renante is 37 years old, married and has three school-age children. He finished his tertiary education but due to lack of job opportunities, he is engaged in corn farming to earn an income and support his family needs. Being a farmer is difficult, but he needs to work hard and strive harder for the sake of his family. He has been in this business for almost nine years and usually earns a profit of PHP 25,000 every harvest season. 

Due to the high cost of commodities and school fees, he wants to increase his yields and income to satisfy their needs. He is asking for a loan of PHP 20,000 to buy seeds, fertilizers and pesticides and to pay for the labor required in corn production. He hopes that the loan will help them to increase their yields. He mentioned that hard work and strong determination will makes his dream comes true.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers and pesticides and to pay for labor

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 29 years old. He is married without children. He sells various goods such as bags, cloths, etc. and he has four years of experience in this business. He works from 6 am until 7 pm every day except on Sunday and he currently employs two people to help him.

Samuel has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to expand his business by purchasing more goods such as bags, cloths, shoes, sugar, etc. to sell. Once his business is expanded, he hopes to reinvest in this business and to save for the future so he will be able to renovate his house.

loans.use: To purchase various goods such as bags, cloth etc to sell

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret lives in Uganda. She is widowed and has five children, none of whom is in school. Margaret has a business selling goats. She has been in this business for five years and she works one day out of every week. Margaret sells her products at the market, by means of wholesale.  Margaret has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more goats. She also generates additional income through rental rooms. The main business challenges for Margaret include transportation and thieves. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a delivery van to ease the transportation of goats and to build rental rooms. Margaret lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more goats to sell

loans.name: Prado Group

texts.en:
Monika, who is in her early 40s, is married with three children who go to school. She has had a grocery business for six years. She works from 6 am to 10 pm and is able to make a fair monthly profit. 

This will be her first loan from Tujijenge Tanzanian, which she wants to use to buy more sodas, water, juice, chapatti and mandanzi.  Her dream is to one day be able to expand her business from two crates to four crates of sodas.

She will share this loan with her loan group "Prado", which has a total of 15 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more sodas, water, juice, chapati and mandanzi.

loans.name: Anwer's Group

texts.en:
Anwer is a very hardworking lady who operates a business selling artificial jewelry, which enables her to pay the utility bills and manage other household expenses. She started this business after the sudden death of her husband few years ago. She has given birth to three sons. Two of her sons work while the third one is looking for work these days. 

Anwer has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her artificial jewelry business. With the loan, she will buy jewelry of different designs in a larger quantity, which will help her offer better variety to her customers and increase her profits. Eid (a Muslim occasion) is about to come and Anwer is confident that with the loan investment, she can increase her sales and earn good profits. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Anwer.

loans.use: To buy artificial jewelry to sell

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is 30 years old and lives in the town of Kijura in the Gulu region of Uganda.  He is married and has three children. All of his children are currently in school. Julius has a retail shop business, which he has had for three years.         

To help expand his business, Julius has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase essential commodities like salt for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Julius hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children.  In the future, Julius hopes to expand his business. Julius is a member of BRAC’s Small enterprise program, which has helped his prospects for the future by improving his business.

loans.use: to purchase essential commodities like salt to sell

loans.name: Docus

texts.en:
Docus is 29 years old and lives in the town of Kijura in the Gulu region of Uganda.  She is married and has two children. All of her children are currently in school. Docus has a shop that sells clothes, which she has had for three years.         

To help expand her business, Docus has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase clothes for resale. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Docus hopes to generate greater profits and buy food for her family. In the future, Docus hopes to expand her business. Docus is a member of BRAC’s Small enterprise (SEP) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business.

loans.use: to purchase clothes for resale.

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her business of making & selling artificial jewelry. She makes jewelry by using different beads which has a high demand among women and girls especially. 

With the loan, she will buy artificial jewelry and also colorful beads to make and sell jewelry in larger quantities to her clients and earn good profits. 

Eid (a Muslims occasion) is about to come and she is very confident that she will increase her sales and profit after the loan investment. 

Her husband is a rickshaw driver by profession. She has six children; four of them study while the youngest two are not of school-going age yet. 

Note: in the photo, the lady raising her hand is Razia.

loans.use: To buy artificial jewelry and beads for making & selling jewelry

loans.name: Laok

texts.en:
Laok, 31, is a married man and father of three school-aged children. He currently opens a small store in front of his house. From this trade he gains a low income per day. Taking time from this business, Laok has been running a small business as a charcoal seller. Here Laok earns about $3 each day also. 

He now wants to improve his charcoal business but has a lack of capital, so he has decided to request some funds from HKL and Kiva. He will use these funds to purchase more charcoal. He expects that this fund will develop his business and gain more revenue everyday.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en:
Joshua is 27 years old and lives in the town of Kijura in the Gulu region of Uganda. He is married and has 1 child who is currently in school. Joshua has a business, a small retail shop that sells video CDs and DVDs, which he has had for 2 years.         

To help expand his business, Joshua has requested a loan of 2000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase video CDs and DVDs for resale. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Joshua hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his child. In the future, Joshua hopes to expand his business. 

Joshua is a member of BRAC’s Small enterprise (SEP) program, which has helped his prospects for the future by improving his business.

loans.use: to purchase video CDs and DVDs for resale.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is 32 years old and lives in the town of Masidi in the Mbarara region of Uganda. He is single and has 4 children. All of his children are currently in school. Robert has a business selling produce like maize, which he has had for 1 year.         

To help expand his business, Robert has requested a loan of 2000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more produce like maize, beans for resale. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Robert hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children.  In the future, Robert hopes to expand his business. 

Robert is a member of BRAC’s Small enterprise (SEP) program, which has helped his prospects for the future by improving his business, and that has changed the living standards of his family.

loans.use: to purchase more produce like maize, beans for resale.

loans.name: Amadeo

texts.en:
Amadeo Jr., a 48-year-old hardworking father of six children, has been a farmer for almost 28 years. He plants rice and vegetables for sale, and usually earns a profit of P30,000 in every harvest season, utilizing his income for food, clothing and allowances for their children. Despite some financial instablity, Amadeo intends to continue sending all of their children to school.

Amadeo also operates a hog-raising business to earn additional income. Due to inadequate capital, he is now requesting a loan of P20,000 to buy feeds, vitamins and additional piglets to raise. He believes that the loan will help him to improve the business as long as he continue to strive. He hopes that his patience and sacrifices will bear fruit someday.

loans.use: to buy feeds, vitamins and additional piglets to raise.

loans.name: Rogers

texts.en:
Rogers is 27 years old and lives in the town of Masidi in the Mbarara region of Uganda.  He is married and has 2 children.  All of his children are currently in school.  Rogers has a business of a retail shop that sells spare parts, which he has had for 4 years.         

To help expand his business, Rogers has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase spare parts for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Rogers hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children.  In the future, Rogers hopes to expand his business.   Rogers is a member of BRAC’s Small enterprise (SEP) program, which has helped his prospects for the future by improving his business.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for resale.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 42 years old and lives in the town of Masidi in the Mbarara region of Uganda.  She is married and has 3 children.  Two of her children are currently in school.  Mary has a business of a small retail shop that sells household goods like plates, which she has had for 3 years.         

To help expand her business, Mary has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase plates and cups for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Mary hopes to generate greater profits and buy food for her family.  In the future, Mary hopes to expand her business.     Mary is a member of BRAC’s Small enterprise (SEP) program which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business.

loans.use: to purchase plates and cups for resale.

loans.name: Moreen

texts.en:
Moreen is 26 years old and lives in the town of Kinubi in the Mbarara region of Uganda.  She is married and has 1 child. Her child is not currently in school.  Moreen has a business of selling clothes, which she has had for 3 years.         

To help expand her business, Moreen has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase clothes for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Moreen hopes to generate greater profits and buy new clothes for herself.  In the future, Moreen hopes to expand her business. Moreen is a member of BRAC’s Small enterprise (SEP) program which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business.

loans.use: to purchase clothes for resale.

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is 29 years old and lives in the town of Kinubi in the Mbarara region of Uganda.  She is married and has 3 children.  All of her children are currently in school.  Aisha has a business of a small retail shop, which she has had for 3 years.         

To help expand her business, Aisha has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase essential commodities like sugar for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Aisha hopes to generate greater profits and buy food for her family.  In the future, Aisha hopes to expand her business.     Aisha is a member of BRAC’s Small enterprise (SEP) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business.

loans.use: to purchase essential commodities like sugar for resale.

loans.name: Mlandizi Kati Group

texts.en:
Alexia, who is in her late 30s, is single with one child who goes to school. She has had a business selling eggs door to door since 2002. She works for three hours from 9 a.m. to noon and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be her 3rd Motisha loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. A Motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania given in the middle of the main loan that motivates borrowers with good credit ratings who pay back their loans smoothly to receive half of the amount of the existing loan before their original loan term has ended. She used the previous loans to sell eggs door to door, sell more chapati and mandanzi, and cover household expenses. She has paid all of her loans successfully. She hopes for a loan to buy more eggs to sell. (She has special customers where she delivers her eggs.) Her dream is to one day be able to have a shop where she can sell all of her products in one place.

She will share this loan with her loan group, "Mlandizi Kati," which has a total of 13 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

loans.use: to buy more eggs to sell.

loans.name: Shahida's Group

texts.en:
Shahida is very active and talented lady who performs her household duties very well. She also operates a clothes-sewing and boutique business to support her husband financially. She displays her dresses in her boutique which helps her attract more customers towards her work. 

She is the mother of six children; the first three work while her three younger children are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. 

Her husband is a rickshaw driver. He also operate a video shop through which he sells movies and DVDs. 

Shahida has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her own business. With the loan, she will buy a new sewing machine and some clothes that will allow her to make more dresses to display for selling and earn better profits. 

She is very confident that her business will go in a positive direction after making an investment into it. 

Note: "In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Shahida ".

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine and clothes for sewing & boutique business

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is 30 years old and lives in the town of Hoima in the Mbarara region of Uganda.  He is married and has no children.  Robert has a business of a small retail shop, which he has had for 3 years.  He raises poultry as his second business.  

To help expand his business, Robert has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase essential commodities like soap for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Robert hopes to generate greater profits and buy food for his family.  In the future, Robert hopes to expand his business into a wholesale shop.   Robert is a member of BRAC’s Small enterprise (SEP) program, which has helped his prospects for the future by improving his business.

loans.use: to purchase essential commodities like soap for resale.

loans.name: Bernadelte

texts.en:
Bernadelte is 25 years old and lives in the town of Hoima in the Mbarara region of Uganda.  She is single and has 2 children.  One of her children is currently in school.  Bernadelte has a business of selling clothes, which she has had for 3 years. She also sells shoes as her second business.        

To help expand her business, she has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase clothes for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Bernadelte hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children.  In the future, she hopes to expand her business.    Bernadelte is a member of BRAC’s Small enterprise (SEP) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business.

loans.use: to purchase clothes for resale.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is 36 years old and lives in the town of Hoima in the Mbarara region of Uganda.  He is single and has 2 children. Both of his children are currently in school.  Paul has a business of a small retail shop, which he has had for 2 years.         

To help expand his business, Paul has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase essential commodities like salt and sugar for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, he hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children.  In the future, he hopes to expand his business.    Paul is a member of BRAC’s Small enterprise (SEP) program, which has helped his prospects for the future by increasing his capital.

loans.use: to purchase essential commodities like salt and sugar for resale.

loans.name: Khol

texts.en:
Khol is the head of a big family in Kompong Thom Province, Cambodia. To improve his financial status, he works everyday driving a motorbike in this province. He can earn about $3 per day to give to his wife. His wife isn't lazy; she sells traditional medicines at home also. They have given birth to five children. Three of them are married and live separate houses. To increase his income, his son is working as a construction worker where he earns enough money per month. 

Khol presently lives in an old house, so he would like to request some funds in order to replace his old house. He will use this loan to purchase a wooden house. He hopes that this funding will make his family reach happiness and a comfortable life. He is very thankful to all kinds of lenders that always see his difficulty.

loans.use: to purchase a wooden house.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is 28 years old and lives in the town of Hoima in the Mbarara region of Uganda.  He is married and has no children.  He has a business of selling mobile phones and phone accessories, which he has had for 2 years.         

To help expand his business, Robert has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase mobile phones and phone accessories for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, he hopes to generate greater profits and buy food for his family.  In the future, he hopes to expand his business. Robert is a member of BRAC’s Small enterprise (SEP) program, which has helped his prospects for the future by improving his business.

loans.use: to purchase mobile phones and phone accessories for resale.

loans.name: C4723 Tubumwe Group

texts.en:
Sarah is 27 years old and is married with eight children. Her business is well-organized and is well known in this business of selling secondhand. Sarah is the team leader of this group which is called "TUBUMWE" in the local language. In the picture, Sarah is the third person from the right side. Her business hours are from 8am until 5pm every day. She has three years of experience in this business. 

Sarah and her team have requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to increase their businesses by buying more secondhand clothes and so on for resale. They will reinvest the profits in their businesses and save for their futures.

loans.use: To purchase more secondhand clothing for resale.

loans.name: Beathe

texts.en:
Beathe, a 30-year-old married woman, operates a well-organized and well-known business selling sheets. Working five days a week from from 8 a.m. until 6 p.m., she has three years of experience.

Beathe has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to buy more sheets to increase her sales volume. She will reinvest any additional profits in her business and save for the future.

loans.use: to purchase more sheets for sale.

loans.name: Aloise

texts.en:
Aloise is 37 years old, married to Irene, and they are blessed with three school-going children. He has been running his general store for the last nine years, earning a monthly profit of KES.8,000, and will use this KES.10,000 loan to purchase additional store stock including bales of rice, flour, beans, sugar, tea leaves, and salt.

With the anticipated profits, Aloise plans to expand his store and apply some starting capital to venture into the quarry business. in the future he hopes for business growth and the finances to educate his children to higher levels of education.

loans.use: to add store stock such as bales of rice, flour, beans, sugar, tea leaves, salt, etc.

loans.name: Claudine

texts.en:
Claudine is 21 years old and is single. Her business is well-organized and is well known in this business of selling chickens. Her business hours are from 6am until 9pm every day.  She has two years of experience and she currently employs three people to help her. 

Claudine has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to increase her business by buying more chickens for resale. She will reinvest any profits in her business and save for her future. Claudine will also be able to buy more chicken feed.

loans.use: To purchase more chickens.

loans.name: Sakina's Group

texts.en:
Sakina is married and has six children. She is a housewife who stays at home and performs her household responsibilities. Three of her children drive rickshaws while the others stay at home.  

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her son who wants to repair his rickshaw because it has a problem and doesn't allow him to work for longer hours. With the loan, her son will buy a new rickshaw body and some spare parts. These will not only help him save his business assets but also allow him to run it smoothly and provide better transport services to his passengers, which will allow him to earn a better income. 

He has been operating his business for past 15 years and Sakina is very confident that the loan investment will prove to be a profitable one for him. 

Note: in the photo, the lady raising her hand is Sakina.

loans.use: To buy a new rickshaw body and spare parts

loans.name: Sofina

texts.en:
Sofina is 39 years old and has been engaged in the buying and selling of fish and meat for almost seven years. Through this business, she can afford to send her three children to school. She works hard to fill the needs of her children. 

She is requesting a loan amount of PHP 7,000 to buy fish, meat and two Styrofoam boxes where she will stock her goods. She wants to develop her business into a bigger one in order to gain a higher income for her children's education.

loans.use: to buy fish, meat and two Styrofoam boxes where she will stock her goods.

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Being a responsible mother, Vivian is concerned with the future of their children. Therefore, Vivian aimed to become financially stable in order to give their children a bright future. She is 32 years old and was blessed with three children. Since farming is the main source of their living, they work hard and strive harder to increase their yields and thereby earn a higher income to satisfy their needs and to finance the education of their children.

Due to financial difficulties, she is asking an additional capital of PHP15,000 to buy fertilizers and pesticides to sustain their rice production. She believes that the loan will help them to increase their production and income. She mentioned that hard work and sacrifices are the only way to attain success. 

In the future, Vivian dreams that their business will grow and their children will all graduate from college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticides to sustain the rice production.

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita is 42 years old and the wife of a farmer. She owns a small variety store in their community where she sells soft drinks, milk, breads and rice. She is earning PHP 3,000 every month which is usually used for daily expenses.

She is requesting a loan amount of PHP 6,000 to buy butter, candies, salt, soy sauce and vinegar as additional goods for her store. She hopes this will help her business to progress in terms of earning a higher profit for the education of her three children.

loans.use: to buy butter, candies, salt, soy sauce and vinegar as additional goods for her store.

loans.name: Kamaro Group

texts.fr:
Leonidas  est un  commerçant âgé de 35ans qui habite   en Province de Ngozi au Nord du Burundi. Il fait le commerce d’articles divers de boutique (haricots,  sel, riz, savons, biscuits, habits pour enfants,…) depuis 3 ans. Il est aussi cultivateur. Il a fréquenté l’école jusqu’en 6e année primaire. Il  est marié et  père de 3enfants dont 1 étudie en 1ere année primaire.

Il demande le crédit Kiva de 180000fbu pour  augmenter son capital en achetant beaucoup d’articles divers de boutique(haricots,  sel, riz, savons, biscuits, habits pour enfants,...)  à revendre pour réaliser de grands bénéfices.
 
Il est membre  du groupe  communautaire« KAMARO».
texts.en: Leonidas is a 35-year old merchant who lives in the Ngozi province in the north of Burundi. He has been in the business of selling sundries (beans, salt, rice, soap, cookies, children's clothing, etc.) for the past three years.  He is also a farmer.  He attended school until the 6th grade.  He is married and father of three children, one of which is in 1st grade.  He is asking for a Kiva loan of 180,000 fbu to increase his working capital and to buy many different shop items (beans, salt, rice, soap, cookies, children's clothing, etc.) for resale to make a large profit.  He is a member of the "KAMARO" community group.

loans.use: augmenter son capital en achetant beaucoup d’articles divers de boutique(haricots,  sel, riz, savons, biscuits, habits pour enfants,...)  à revendre pour réaliser de grands bénéfices

loans.name: Antonio

texts.en:
Antonio is 48 years old and has been a tricycle operator for seven years. He was married and blessed with three children, but unfortunately was unable to make it last (they were separated). Now, he is earning to support himself through operating his tricycle every day. He usually earns about PHP 400 daily which he uses to buy food for himself.

He is requesting a loan amount of PHP6,000 to buy new tires and paint for his tricycle. He wants to provide better transport customer service in order to increase the number of his customers, as it will boost his daily income. He hopes to improve his living as he pursues working.

loans.use: to buy new tires and paint for his tricycle

loans.name: Jun

texts.en:
Jun is 30 years old and single. He runs a sari-sari (variety) store business because of the poor quality of his life. He wishes to become one of the well-heeled men in the community, so he patiently sells cooking oil, breads, bath soap and soft drinks at his store.

He has been in this kind of occupation for two years and is hoping to increase his income by asking for a loan of PHP 3,000 to buy butter for breads, salt, vinegar and canned goods as an additional source of profit in his store. He hopes to earn more for the betterment of his life and also to save for his future.

loans.use: to buy butter, salt, vinegar and canned goods.

loans.name: Odette

texts.en:
Odette is 49 years old, married and has three children. Her business is well-organized and well known. She sells drinks such as local drinks and soft drinks. Her business hours are from 6 a.m. until 10 p.m. every day.  She has five years of experience and she currently employs one person to help her. 

Odette has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to increase her business by buying more drinks such as local drinks and soft drinks for sale. With any profits, she will reinvest in her business and save for her future.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks such as local drinks and soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase grocery goods.

loans.name: Estrelita

texts.en:
Estrelita is a 49-year-old widow. Her husband died from cancer of the brain. She has five children to provide for. Despite the difficulty of pursuing their lives alone, she is working hard to grant their daily needs such as food.

Estrelita engages in piggery as her primary source of income. She is requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy feed for her hogs. She hopes to earn a higher income so that she can save for emergencies. She doesn't want to experience again to loss the one she loves because of lack of finance.

loans.use: to buy feed for her hogs.

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
Beatriz is 52 years old, married to a farmer and blessed with three children. She is very industrious wife and mother. She has enabled her children to finish their desired courses through her hard work.

She has been operating her hog fattening business for five years and earning an average net income of PHP 10,000 each selling season.

She herself finished her elementary grades and never entered secondary education due to poverty. So she is being patient in her work because, as she says, a lot of money comes from pigs; just be patient and industrious. She is not a degree holder nor a college graduate but is earning a high amount of income.

She is asking for a loan of PHP 7,000 to buy five more hogs to raise in order to earn more income for the betterment of their lives.

loans.use: to buy five more hogs to raise.

loans.name: Merly

texts.en:
Merly is a 35-year-old, industrious mother who has a business fattening hogs. She has been blessed with five children. In order to provide for their needs, she works hard. She has been raising hogs for 10 years, and she earns 4,000 PHP every selling season.

She is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP to buy feed and vitamins (vetracin) for her hogs. She hopes to raise healthy hogs in order to increase her net income.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins (vetracin) for her hogs

loans.name: Damien

texts.en:
Damien is 34 years old, married, and has three children between three and seven years old. He sells charcoal. The borrower put leaves on the sacks of charcoal to cover and then sales sacks in wholesale not in retail. He has three years of experience in this business. He works from 7:00 a.m. until 8:00 p.m. every weekday and he currently employs one person to help him. 

Damien has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to expand his business by purchasing more charcoal covered in the sacks for sale. Once his business is expanded, he hopes to reinvest in this business and to save for the future.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoals covered in the sacks for sale.

loans.name: Dominador

texts.en:
Dominador is 58 years old and has a sari-sari (variety) store. He has been operating this for three years and earns 1,500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) every month. As an entrepreneur, he wants to earn more than his current profit, so he is being industrious and has the patience to sell in his store despite  the debts of some of his customers. 

He wants to stock more grocery items such as soft drinks, biscuits, breads, and butter in his store to sell, so he took out a loan of 7,000 PHP from Alalay Sa Kaunlaran Inc. as an additional source of profit and also to avoid bankruptcy.

loans.use: to stock more grocery items such as soft drinks, biscuits, breads, and butter in his store

loans.name: Tsendsuren

texts.en:
Tsendsuren is a 29-year-old, young Mongolian lady who lives with her fiancé, younger brother and mother on her sister’s plot of land which is located in an outer ger district (district without basic infrastructure) of the capital Ulaanbaatar city. 

Tsendsuren got a specialized bachelor degree in Accounting in 2007 and has worked at local companies for two years. Regardless of her profession, since 2009, she has been operating a clothing business at a small stall in an indoor market. Tsendsuren usually imports her products from Ereen, a border city of China. Her younger brother works in the local province.  

She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan from Kiva lenders to import more fall-designed clothes in order to increase her working capital and raise income. She is a repeat client of our NBFI and she wishes to have her own clothing store in the future.

loans.use: to import more clothes for the upcoming season

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena is 29 years old. As her source of income, she has engaged herself in a sari-sari (variety) store. She has been doing this for two years and earns an average of 4,000 PHP every month which she uses for daily expenses such as food.

She is requesting a loan amount of 9,000 PHP to buy sugar, cooking oil, coffee and vinegar as additional goods to her store. She hopes these goods will contribute a higher income for the betterment of her business. She is working hard as a store owner for the future of her children.

loans.use: to buy sugar, cooking oil, coffee and vinegar

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma is 53 years old. She engages in buying and selling fruits and vegetables as her primary source of income. She sells in the market every Thursday and Sunday (market day) and works in her vegetable garden for the remaining days.

She is requesting a loan amount of 9,000 PHP to buy beans, avocados and bananas as additional goods to sell. She hopes this will increase her income every market day. She dreams of getting out from poverty, so she is being industrious and hardworking.

loans.use: to buy beans, avocados and bananas as additional goods to sell

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is a farmer who lives in the town of Banga, South Cotabato. She is 31 years old and married with 1 child.

Irene grows rice and corn crops then sells her harvest at the market. She is able to provide for her family’s basic needs through farming. Irene is planning to use her loan to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. She hopes to earn more and be able to save for her child’s education.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Jeannette

texts.en:
Jeannette is 28 years old and is married with one child who is 2 years old. Her business of selling curtains is well-organized and well-known. Her business hours are from 8am until 7pm every day except on the weekend. She has four years of experience and currently employs one person to help her. 

Jeannette has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to increase her business by buying more curtains for sale. With any profits, she will reinvest in her business and save for the future.

loans.use: to purchase more curtains for sale

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen is married and her husband is involved in selling clothes. His shop is located in the nearby market and he sells different variety of clothes to his customers for good profits. Nasreen is a housewife, staying at her home and doing her household responsibilities.  

She is the mother of three sons and a daughter. Her eldest son is an electrician and repairs electrical items such as air conditions and fridges and freezers while the second one is a painter. Her remaining two children stay at home.
 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husband’s clothes-selling business. With the loan, he will put more variety of clothes into his shop and that will allow him to offer better choice to his customers for purchasing. 

Nasreen is very confident that her husband’s business will become more profitable after the loan investment and she will be able to provide better living facilities to her family in result. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Nasreen.

loans.use: To buy clothes for selling.

loans.name: Leonardo

texts.en:
Leonardo is 35 years old. For almost one year, he has been operating a tricycle. He is a college graduate but cannot find a better job. He cares for his daughter while his wife works in another country. They are working hard to save for their daughter's future.

Leonardo works daily to lessen the financial burden and not just rely on the money his wife sends. He is requesting a loan for 7,000 PHP from Alalay Sa Kaunlaran Inc. to buy new tires for his tricycle. He wants to provide better service to his customers and not ask his wife again for the money. He hopes to generate a higher income to pay the family's obligations and for the betterment of their lives.

loans.use: to buy new tires for his tricycle

loans.name: Fidélité Plus Group

texts.en:
Jean is a leader of the community bank named “Fidélité Plus” which is composed of 13 microentrepreneurs. They are united in solidarity to obtain loans from Kiva through the MFI HOPE DRC with the goal of developing their businesses. 

Jean sells food in the mid-eastern area of Kinshasa. He has been in business since 2003. His beginning capital was $50. Currently, through his sales, Jean makes about $15 per day. He plans to use the next loan to purchase two bags of milk to resell in order to increase his income. He is a trustworthy client of the MFI HOPE DRC, having six times received and properly repaid loans. He dreams to someday open a boutique and a drugstore in his area. Jean is 48 years old, married and the father of eight children whose ages range from 8 to 24 years old. All of them attend school.

loans.use: to purchase two bags of milk to resell at profit

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena, a 20-year-old young mother of two children. has been buying and selling bananas for four years to serve the daily needs of her family. Despite her young age, Rowena is proficient in life, working hard to ensure that her children avoid making the mistakes she made, such as entering into an early marriage.

Seeking to continue her interrupted dreams through her children, she is requesting a loan of P7,000 to buy bananas, avocados and ginger as additional goods to sell every market day. The extra income will be allotted to her children's education.

loans.use: to buy bananas, avocados and ginger as additional goods to sell.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 33 years old and has been engaged in the buying and selling of fruits and vegetables for five years.  She usually earns P700 within two market days which is not enough to provide for the needs of her family.  For additional income, she also entertains field work such as the harvesting of rice every harvesting season.

She wishes to improve her business by asking for a loan in the amount of P8,000 to buy bananas, eggplants, and string beans as additional goods to sell.  She hopes to gain more profit by prioritizing her buying and selling business so that she does not need to find another occupation.  Jocelyn wants to earn a higher income for the future of her three children.

loans.use: to buy bananas, eggplants, and string beans as additional goods to sell

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic is 32 years old and is engaged in buying and selling of fruits and vegetables.  She has been doing this over 16 years and earns a net income of P2,000 every month.  She is anxious because her income every month is not enough to send her eldest to college, so she doubles her perseverance just to provide the educational needs of her children.

She is requesting a loan amount of P10,000 to buy bananas, avocados, and beans to sell in the market.  She hopes to exceed her current profit to pay for her obligation to Alalay sa Kaunlaran Inc. She hopes to be able to save for the family's everyday needs, especially for the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy bananas, avocados, and beans to sell in the market.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase potatoes, onions, maize, tomatoes, green vegetables, and fruits to add to her stock.

loans.name: Herminia

texts.en:
“Although no matter how hard is life, I will remain strong for my children sake”. This is the phrase of Herminia, a 52 year-old woman who sells fruits and vegetables as a source of income. She was alone to raise her three children because her husband died due to a severe peptic ulcer which was not treated soon enough. 

In the desire to improve their lifestyle, she is requesting from Alalay sa Kaunlaran Inc. a loan of P8,000 to buy more bananas, munggo seeds, avocado and ginger to sell in the market to have more income for their daily needs. She wishes to build a new business such as sari-sari (variety) store as an additional source of income. She hopes to accomplish it with help form ASKI and through her diligence and perseverance.

loans.use: to buy more bananas, munggo seeds, avocado and ginger to sell

loans.name: Thol

texts.en:
Thol is 37 years old.  She is a widow with one child living under her  care. She is a hardworking woman. Thol has been generating her income by raising pigs. From this business, she earns approximately $5USD each day. 

Thol would like to expand her business but lacks capital.  She wishes to request some funds to buy concentrated feed for fattening her pigs. She wants to increase her business so that her micro-enterprise will grow more each day through this loan. This will allow her to provide her customers with the best product whenever her pigs are ready to be sold. Thol’s business was started as a new source of revenue so that she could improve the quality of life for her family and provide the best education for her child.  This is the first loan with Kiva and the fourth loan with HKL partner. She said that becoming a member of this micro-finance group was an excellent decision because obtaining a loan is an easier, faster process and has a low interest rate. She is very grateful to all kind lenders that always help her family.

loans.use: to purchase pig feed.

loans.name: Mary Jean

texts.en:
According to Mary Jean, " patience and hard work" are the only weapons to fight poverty. She is now 39 and a mother of two. They live harmoniously in a village, planting and harvesting rice and vegetables for sale. They work hard and endure hardships to earn income and provide their family needs. They aim to increase their crop yields and income to be able to finance the tuition fees and allowances of their children who are now at college level.

Due to inadequate capital, Mary Jean is asking for a loan of P15,000 to buy fertilizers and pesticides to sustain their rice production. She is hoping that this loan will help them to increase their crop yields. She believes that someday, their business will grow and become fruitful as long as they continue to work and strive.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticides to sustain rice production.

loans.name: Tuimizane Group

texts.fr: La cliente Kasiwa, leader du groupe d’affaire «Tuimizane», est jeune entrepreneur, âgée de 44  ans, mère de 8 enfants, qui étudient tous et d’autres ont leurs foyers. Elle est  vendeuse de souliers.  Son mari est aviateur. Elle installe ses marchandises dans un marché communal CADECO au centre ville. Il y a 4 ans révolus qu’elle exerce ces petites activités génératrices de revenus de ce genre. Cependant, elle vient de réaliser  6 cycles avec le crédit de Hekima. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir  de s’approvisionner avec  40 paires de souliers à marchander et le reste sera injecté dans le projet de construction.  En plus, elle souhaite  voir ses enfants grandir confortablement  et agrandir son entreprise.  La cliente remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres femmes exclues de banque classique.
texts.en: Kasiwa is the leader of the Tuimizane group. She is a 44-year old entrepreneur and the mother of 8 children, all of whom are students. Kasiwa is a shoe seller, and her husband is a pilot. She sells her wares at the Cadeco municipal market in the center of town. Kasiwa has been a small retailer for 4 years and has already completed 6 loan cycles with Hekima. This new loan would allow her to buy 40 pairs of shoes for resale. The remainder of the money would be used fund a construction project. Kasiwa would like to grow her business and watch her children grow up in comfort. She would like to thank Hekima for helping disadvantaged women excluded from regular bank lending channels.

loans.use: to buy 40 pairs of shoes and some building materials

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Ararati Group

texts.fr: La cliente Mulisa, leader du groupe d’affaire «Ararati », est jeune entrepreneur, âgée de 40  ans, mère de 7 jeunes enfants, qui étudient. Elle est  vendeuse de souliers dames, sacs à mains, etc.  Son mari est chômeur. Elle installe ses marchandises dans un magasin au centre commercial Birere. Il y a 2 ans révolus qu’elle exerce ces petites activités génératrices de revenus de ce genre. Cependant, elle vient de réaliser  10 cycles avec le crédit de Hekima. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir  de s’approvisionner avec  40 paires de souliers, 20 sacs à mains  à marchander.  En plus, elle souhaite  voir ses enfants grandir confortablement  et agrandir son entreprise.  La cliente remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres femmes exclues de banque classique.
texts.en:
Mulisa is the head of the business group “Ararati". She is a young entrepreneur, age 40, and the mother of seven young children who attend school. She sells ladies’ footwear, handbags, etc. Her husband is unemployed. She displays her merchandise in a store at the Birere shopping mall. She has been practicing such income-generating activities for two years. 

She has completed 10 loan cycles with the Hekima microfinance institution. This new loan will allow her to stock up on merchandise by buying 40 pairs of shoes and 20 handbags for resale. She wants her children to grow up comfortably, and she would also like to expand her business. 

Mulisa wishes to thank the Hekima MFI for helping poor women who do not have access to traditional banks.

loans.use: to buy 40 pairs of shoes and 20 handbags for resale

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizer and other materials.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Chan, who is 30 years old, is living in Preveng province and sells groceries, with $4 per day as her income. Her husband is doing farming.   He can earn $4 per day. Chan has three children who are 8, 5 and 2 years old.  One is studying at school. Every month, she has to spend $60 on food, $8 on electricity, $4 on school fees, and $10 on other expenses. 

She would like to request a loan of $1200 to buy more goods for her grocery store.  In the future, she hopes to have enough money to extend her store by selling more goods. For her children, she wants to send them to study in the university when they finish high school.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her grocery store

loans.name: C13005 Tuzamurane Group

texts.en:
Julienne is 29 years old and is single. Her business of selling vegetables, rice, beans, bananas, etc., is well-organized and well-known. 

Julienne is the team leader of this group which is called "Tuzamurane" in the local language. In the picture, Julienne is the first person from the right side.  Her business hours are from 7am until 5 pm every day except on Saturday.  

Julienne and her team have requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to increase their businesses by buying more products (beans, bananas, vegetables, rice, and so on) to sell. They will reinvest any profits back into their businesses and save for their future.

loans.use: To purchase more products such as beans, bananas, rice, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Agichuluun

texts.en: Agichuluun is 23 years old and lives with his wife and son in a ger, a Mongolian yurt, in Govisumber province of Mongolia. His wife studies at the local vocational training center, but this year, she is staying at home, taking care of her one-year-old son. Agichuluun graduated from the Buddhist Religious University in 2008. He then returned home. He provides religious services to locals. He has many clients because of his education and experience. Also, Agichuluun operates a small grocery shop. His shop is located right next to his yurt. He bought a car with his previous loan. Now he is planning to build a house and has already purchased 800 bricks. He is a diligent man who is requesting a 2,700,000 MNT (Mongolian Tughrik) loan to buy construction materials and build his house.

loans.use: To buy construction materials

loans.name: Annah

texts.en:
Annah is 34 years old and married with five children between the ages of four and fourteen years.  She has been running her grocery store for the last seven months and has been making a monthly profit of KES 6,000.  

She has been loaned KES 10,000, which she plans to use to purchase kale, onions, potatoes, tomatoes, vegetables, and fruits to add to her stock.

With the anticipated profit, she plans to become a fruit vendor in Lukenya.  In the near future, she hopes to start supplying fruits and vegetables beyond Lukenya and its surrounding area.

loans.use: To purchase kale, onions, potatoes, tomatoes, vegetables, and fruits to add to her stock.

loans.name: Sieng

texts.en:
Sieng, who is 59 years old, sells groceries with her husband at their house in the village.  Their income is $10 per day. She has two children who are 26 and 28 years old.  All of her children have their own careers and can make $10 per day each. 

Every month, Sieng has to spend $80 on food, $10 on electricity, $5 on rental house fees, and $15 on transportation. She would like to request a loan of $1,000 to buy chicken and chicken feed for her son’s career.

loans.use: To buy chicken and chicken feed for her son's career.

loans.name: Winner Plus Group

texts.en:
